title: How to Stop a Baby from Vomiting

steps.title: Wait 30 to 60 minutes before giving your baby fluids.
steps.content: Wait 30 to 60 minutes before giving your baby fluids. If your baby has just thrown up, you might worry that they'll become dehydrated. Instead of giving them breastmilk or formula right away, give their stomach a little time to settle. If your baby vomits multiple times within an hour, call the doctor or nurse helpline. [1] X Research source Most babies won't want to eat or drink anything for a while after they throw up.

steps.title: Offer your baby 1 to 2 teaspoons (4.9 to 9.9 ml) of breastmilk or formula.
steps.content: Offer your baby 1 to 2 teaspoons (4.9 to 9.9 ml) of breastmilk or formula . Once you've waited a while, try to feed your baby for 5 to 10 minutes. Then see if your baby can keep it down. If they do, continue to feed 1 to 2 teaspoons (4.9 to 9.9 ml) for at least 1 to 2 hours. [2] X Research source If your baby can't keep the breastmilk or formula down, wait for 30 to 60 minutes before trying again.

steps.title: Give your baby electrolyte solution to prevent dehydration.
steps.content: Give your baby electrolyte solution to prevent dehydration. If your baby has vomited more than 3 times within a few hours, they may lose too much water and electrolytes. Purchase an electrolyte solution to give your baby if they're over 3 months old. If your baby is under 3 months old, get medical advice. Continue to feed your baby formula or breastmilk as well. [3] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source If your baby is over 6 months old, you can also offer 1 ⁄ 2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of apple juice.

steps.title: Feed your older baby bland foods.
steps.content: Feed your older baby bland foods. If your baby is over 6 months old and has already started eating solids, gradually reintroduce food. Wait to reintroduce food until your baby has kept down fluids for 8 hours. Then give a few spoonfuls of soft, bland food, such as: [4] X Research source Applesauce Pear puree Mashed bananas Infant cereal mixed with water, formula, or breastmilk

steps.title: Position your baby so they're upright or on their side.
steps.content: Position your baby so they're upright or on their side. If your baby is awake, hold them so they're sitting upright or cradled on their side against you. This will make it easier to keep your baby from swallowing vomit if they begin to throw up. [5] X Research source If you're putting your baby down to sleep , lay them on their side or back to prevent them from choking on vomit. If your baby has a birth defect, such as a cleft palate, position them on their side when putting them down.

steps.title: Ask your doctor before giving the baby any medication.
steps.content: Ask your doctor before giving the baby any medication. If your baby has a fever, the doctor might recommend that you give an over-the-counter (OTC) infant fever reducer. If your baby doesn't have a fever, ask the doctor before giving an anti-nausea medication. [6] X Research source If your baby is under 6 months old, you should also ask before giving them an OTC infant fever reducer. If your baby is under 2 months and has a fever, call your doctor right away to see what they recommend.

steps.title: Sing or talk to your baby in soothing tones.
steps.content: Sing or talk to your baby in soothing tones. Your baby is probably frightened and needs extra comforting from you. Most babies prefer to be held more when they're feeling unwell, so hold your baby and walk around. While some babies might enjoy being rocked, it may make your baby feel nauseated. Talk or sing to your baby in a calm voice to help reassure them. If you're feeling exhausted caring for your baby, it's important to ask for help from a partner, family, or friends.

steps.title: Keep the house quiet and calm while your baby is sick.
steps.content: Keep the house quiet and calm while your baby is sick. Try to limit the amount of noise and activity so your baby can feel rested during recovery. Dim the lights and play relaxing music in order to make a comfortable environment for your baby. [7] X Research source Avoid running loud machines or appliances if the noise seems to bother your baby. Since you know your baby best, you'll know when your baby is feeling better and ready to resume their usual routine.

steps.title: Track how often your baby vomits.
steps.content: Track how often your baby vomits. Because so many different things can cause your baby to vomit, it's important to pay attention to how frequently your baby vomits. Write down every time your baby vomits and whether they vomited after eating. This will be valuable information for your baby's doctor. [8] X Research source Keep in mind that vomiting is more forceful than spitting up. There will also be more vomit than when your baby spits up.

steps.title: Monitor your baby's fluid intake and number of wet diapers.
steps.content: Monitor your baby's fluid intake and number of wet diapers. If your baby vomits more than once, you'll need to ensure that your baby doesn't become dehydrated. Pay attention to how much breastmilk, formula, or water your baby is drinking and track how many wet diapers your baby has throughout the day. The recommended amount of fluid for your baby will depend on your baby's weight and overall health, so doctors usually ask you to track how many wet diapers they produce in a day. If your baby has fewer than 6 wet diapers in a 24-hour period, they're becoming dehydrated.

steps.title: Take your baby's temperature to check for fever.
steps.content: Take your baby's temperature to check for fever. Insert a digital thermometer into your baby's ear, armpit, or rectum until it reads your baby's temperature. If your baby has a temperature of 100.4 °F (38.0 °C) or higher, they have a fever. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Because they're inaccurate, avoid using digital pacifier thermometers or fever strips.

steps.title: Contact the doctor if your baby vomits more than once or has a fever.
steps.content: Contact the doctor if your baby vomits more than once or has a fever. You should also pay attention to any strange colors in the vomit. For example, call the doctor right away if you see blood or green in the vomit. If your baby continues to retch without producing any vomit, contact your doctor. Let the doctor know if your baby is projectile vomiting.

steps.title: Get emergency attention if your baby is dehydrated or lethargic.
steps.content: Get emergency attention if your baby is dehydrated or lethargic. It's good to seek emergency medical attention if your baby is under 3 months old and shows any signs of illness. You should also get emergency attention if your older baby suddenly seems very tired or dehydrated. Signs of dehydration include: [10] X Research source Listlessness Dry lips or mouth No wet diapers within 4 to 6 hours A sunken fontanel (soft spot on the head) No tears when crying
